title: Success rates for pothole compensation claims to Sussex councils drops to one in six
text:
Balcombe celebrates permission to build solar park 
Roger Williams, East Sussex County Council head of highways, said every compensation claim was “carefully assessed” and claims were rejected because the council had carried out its duty to inspect roads frequently, repairing potholes quickly once they had been identified. 
He added: “The fact we enjoyed a milder winter than in recent years may have been a factor in the reduction in pothole compensation claims. 
“However, for us the primary reason is the £70 million we’ve invested in improving our roads network over the last four years.” 
A Brighton and Hove City Council spokeswoman said the authority had benefited from government funding supporting its own preventative maintenance programme to protect the city’s highways. 
She added: “For a claim to succeed, anyone seeking compensation for damage caused by a road defect must prove that the council was negligent in its duty.” 
A West Sussex County Council spokesman said: “There are two reasons for this reduction. Share article 
“Firstly we invested £30 million pounds in resurfacing and repairing our rural and residential roads – on top of what we already spend – to make the roads safer.
